newsitem.title: BANGLADESH: IMF says it continues talks with Dhaka on loan.
newsitem.headline: IMF says it continues talks with Dhaka on loan.

text.p: A senior official of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) said on Thursday the Fund would continue talks with Bangladesh on a possible loan, but said the country should first remove "structural rigidities".

"Bangladesh still has got some structural rigidities in a number of areas and the government should deal with those strongly," Margaret Kelly, a senior adviser in the IMF's Asia and Pacific department, told a news conference.
Kelly is leading an eight-member IMF team to Bangladesh for talks with government officials on a soft-term balance of payment support and other fiscal and monetary issues.
Kelly did not elaborate on the structural rigidities"
She, however, said Bangladesh must strengthen its banking system dogged by huge non-performing loans, and make efforts to privatatise public enterprises or close down loss making ones.
The official said Bangladesh needed to liberalise further its trade regime and intensify fiscal reforms.
Bangladesh has recently asked for soft term loans from the IMF as the country is facing a tighter balance of payment position because of its depleting foreign exchange reserves.
Kelly would not say the amount of the possible IMF loan that would be available from the fund's Enhanced Structural Adjustment Facility (ESAF).
Finance Minister S A M S Kibria recently told reporters that Bangladesh might seek $600 million from the IMF.
Kelly appreciated the government's success in containing inflation and growth in agricultural production.
"The present government made a good pick up by containing the rate of inflation and reaping a very good harvest during the current year," she said.
Finance Ministry officials said the current inflation rate is 3.2 percent.
